subject: Productivity
title: MoSCoW Prioritization
description: A micro-lesson that makes MoSCoW Prioritization usable.

hook.text: Software teams can't build everything. MoSCoW forces them to sort features into four brutal categories.

buildup.text: Must have: non-negotiable. Should have: important. Could have: nice. Won't have: not now.

discovery.text: Dai Clegg created MoSCoW at Oracle in 1994. It prevents feature creep by making trade-offs explicit.

twist.text: The hardest category is Won't Have. Stakeholders hate hearing no. But saying yes to everything kills projects.

climax.text: MoSCoW works beyond software: events, budgets, and personal goals all benefit from forced categorization.

punchline.text: Sorting by priority is easy. Saying no is the hard part.

quiz.question: What does the W in MoSCoW stand for?
